thread.title: Dave Smith quits as NRL CEO
thread.title_full: Dave Smith quits as NRL CEO

author: Nick Walshaw
title: Dave Smith quits as NRL CEO
text:
Video Image Smith proud of legacy 1:59 NRL: CEO Dave Smith says he is proud of the legacy he has left during his three years in the game. Smith resigned from his post as CEO earlier today.
October 20th 2015 4 hours ago /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/NRL/ Dave Smith has quit after a tumultuous three years as the boss of the National Rugby League. Pic Stephen Cooper
Nick Walshaw The Daily Telegraph DAVE Smith arrived in rugby league with no idea who captained the Kangaroos.
“But I wasn’t signed on to be selector,” the departing CEO laughed on Tuesday. “Or to coach.
“My mandate was to put the game in a better place ... and I believe I’ve done that.”
Chatting with The Daily Telegraph inside his office at League HQ, Smith has just been asked to define his three years running the National Rugby League.
For isn’t this the debate every time someone goes?
Asking if the man who gave us Benji Barba and removed the shoulder charge, who knew spreadsheets if not a Test dressingroom, has left the game better than on arrival?
His critics, of course, say: No.
Dave Smith has quit as NRL CEO. Picture Craig Greenhill Source: News Corp Australia
Adamant that, apart from failing to secure that $1.7 billion broadcast deal, Smithy also leaves the game with lower crowds, decreased participation rates and a couple of clubs whose finances sit somewhere between ordinary and One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest.
GONE: Smith quits as NRL CEO
REACTION: How fans and colleague reacted to Smith announcement
BUZZ: Eastern suburbs banker didn’t get NRL
PODCAST: BUZZ ON DAVE SMITH’S DECISION TO WALK AWAY
Supporters, however, ask if those clubs would even exist without the Welshman?
Stressing how, thanks to business acumen of this bullish banker, league has replaced barneys with bucketloads of stadium funding.
Rated its backside of with Origin, too.
Elsewhere, entering new markets thanks not only to social media, the Auckland Nines and a spotlight on the Jillaroos, but a game safer for those Gladiators who play it.
“This is a stronger sport now than when I started,’’ Smith continued. “And I’m proud of that.
“I’m not for a minute saying the job is complete. It never is.
“What I will say though is that, thanks to the team we have here at the NRL, thanks to the commission, this game now has a strong platform from which to progress.
“And it can do that while in arguably the best shape it’s been ever.”
Who should replace Dave Smith as NRL CEO? Certainly Smith has been kept busy during his time at the helm.
Arriving at his post a day early to deal with ASADA, the CEO on Tuesday entered his farewell presser having just learned Hazem El Masri, an NRL Ambassador, had been charged with domestic assault.
In between, too, the businessman has traversed everything from the heartfelt ‘Rise For Alex’ round through to the Gold Coast drugs saga, bubblers and a NSW skipper insulting him on Twitter.
REPLACEMENT: Who fills Smith’s shoes?
RESIGNATION: Smith says ‘time is right’
TIMELINE: All the significant dates in Smith’s tenure
Yep, rugby league is that sort of beast.
But how well Smithy gets that, well, debate continues there too.
“But the game, it’s under my skin now,’’ the father-of-two insisted. “I’ve been able to look under the covers, see the humbleness of rugby league.
“I love that about the game.”
And as for how league best manages its mix of business and brutality moving forward?
“By finding the balance between emotion and logic,’’ he said. “Sport is emotional, no question.
Gallop remains coy 0:34 NRL: Former CEO David Gallop has tried to steer clear of making any comment about the resignation of Dave Smith.
October 20th 2015 5 hours ago /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/NRL/ “But when you’ve got a background where you’re not ingrained in the organisation of sport, when you come in you can be more objective.
“And I believe that has helped.
“I’m proud of this game because I think it’s the best game. I’m proud because my young daughters now think it’s the best game too.”
 NRL ‘stronger’ now than when I started: Smith
